1.content: Battle of Fort Sumter initiates the Civil War. The upper south, including Virginia, secedes as a result.

2.content: In an effort to encourage settlement of the West, the Homestead Act is passed.  It offered 160 acres of land to settlers who stayed 5 years.

3.content: The Freedman’s Bureau provides education, wage negotiation, and other help to ex-slaves to ease the transition after emancipation.

5.content: The National Banking Act created a national banking system, provided federal war loans and established a national currency.

6.content: Lincoln first suspends the writ of habeas corpus for a suspect accused of hindering Union troops moving from Baltimore to D.C.

7.content: The Emancipation Proclamation takes effect, freeing the slaves in any area under active rebellion against the Union.

8.content: The Thirteenth Amendment is ratified, abolishing slavery

9.content: Abraham Lincoln is assassinated.  Vice President Andrew Johnson becomes president to oversee Reconstruction.

10.content: Andrew Johnson is impeached by the radical Republican-controlled House of Representatives.

24.content: The Fourteenth Amendment is ratified, promising birthright citizenship and equal protection under the law.

11.content: The Fifteenth Amendment is ratified, extending the right to vote to black men

12.content: An economic panic (recession) starting in this year further shifts Northern attitudes away from Reconstruction and toward the economy.

13.content: A compromise in this year hands the presidency to Rutherford B. Hayes in exchange for the North abandoning Reconstruction.

14.content: Booker T. Washington articulates a controversial vision of education ahead of political rights in his Atlanta Compromise speech.

15.content: The Supreme Court legitimizes race-based segregation with its Plessy v. Ferguson decision.

16.content: The KKK is founded in Tennessee to violently limit ex-slaves freedom, leading to lynchings and limited political, economic, and social equality.

17.content: Lincoln wins re-election after Sherman’s victory at Atlanta. Sherman then enacts his total war campaign “March to the Sea”

18.content: The Union wins the Battle of Antietam, allowing Lincoln to issue the Emancipation Proclamation which convinces Europe to not ally with Confederacy.

19.content: South Carolina secedes in December of this year. Other lower south states follow in the new year

20.content: The 54th Massachusetts Regiment is formed, the first segregated unit of black troops. They helped convince many that blacks deserved equality.

21.content: President Johnson is impeached by the House of Reps, but not convicted by the Senate, for preventing the Republicans Reconstruction plan.

22.content: Radical Republicans pass the Military Reconstruction Plan, imposing military rule on southern states to dictate reunification.

23.content: A new wave of teenagers achieve the American Dream of earning a top-notch public education from Ms. Sadlon and Mr. Colglazier. Huzzah!!!
